author: yecril71pl
body:
<!--

For Windows PowerShell 5.1 issues, suggestions, or feature requests please use the following link instead:
Windows PowerShell [UserVoice](https://windowsserver.uservoice.com/forums/301869-powershell)

This repository is **ONLY** for PowerShell Core 6 and PowerShell 7+ issues.

- Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- Search the existing issues.
- Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- Refer to the [known issues](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/known-issues-ps6).

-->

## Steps to reproduce

```powershell
Start-PSBuild
```

## Expected behavior

```none
git: The term 'git' is not recognized as the name of a cmdlet, function, script file, or operable program.
Check the spelling of the name, or if a path was included, verify that the path is correct and try again.
```

## Actual behavior

```none
`PowerShell\PowerShell.Common.props(17,5): error MSB3073: The command "git describe --abbrev=60 --long" exited with code 9009`
```

## Environment data

<!-- provide the output of $PSVersionTable -->

```none
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.0.2
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.0.2
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.18363
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body: The error comes from MSBuild and we can not improve it.

comments.author: yecril71pl
comments.body: We can refuse to invoke `MSBuild` if `git` is not found.

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body: We can. But git is main prerequisite for the project. Perhaps we already have this in `Start-PSBootstrap`.

comments.author: yecril71pl
comments.body:
The command `Start-PSBootstrap`, which should really be called `Install-Prerequisites`, is documented to call `Install-Dotnet`.  It is also documented that you can call `Install-Dotnet` separately.  `git` is not mentioned.
Aside, the situation when an application requires `git` to be built is worrying. `git` is a code management tool, not a build tool, and Intenet access should not be required to get things built in a properly configured environment (with all prerequisites installed).

comments.author: vexx32
comments.body:
`git` requirement doesn't necessarily imply it's accessing the internet, merely that metadata from the repository is used as part of the build so that a given build has a version attached to it (typically it's the git commit ID, IIRC, unless the current commit is tagged).

We can document this, but IMO there's no good reason to remove git from the build.

comments.author: yecril71pl
comments.body:
```powershell
Start-PSBootstrap
```
> Installing PowerShell build dependencies
> dotnet is already installed.  Skipping installation.

No `git` whatsoever.

comments.author: msftbot[bot]
comments.body: This issue has been marked as answered and has not had any activity for **1 day**. It has been closed for housekeeping purposes.

comments.author: msftbot[bot]
comments.body:
:tada:This issue was addressed in #13227, which has now been successfully released as `v7.1.0-preview.7`.:tada:

Handy links:
* [Release Notes](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases/tag/v7.1.0-preview.7)

title: Start-PSBuild: cryptic error message MSB3073
